data.text: Improving governance and fighting #corruption could lead to more inclusive and sustainable growth. Check out our new webpage for articles, blogs, reports, videos, and more on the IMF's work on this topic. https://t.co/pa5FJfyCv9 https://t.co/qLOrA21t5M

Deputy Managing Director Antoinette M. Sayeh: Economic divergence can also weigh down long-term growth in advanced economies. We must act now. Here are three areas where we need multilateral solutions. 

Read her speech at #ChamberGlobalForum:  https://t.co/9Vgq4CUrKe @USChamber https://t.co/z5v7IJEfsb

Many countries received IMF financing to counter the pandemic while also committing to transparency and accountability measures. 

Today, we release a table updating the implementation status of these measures. How has your country fared? #IMFBlog: https://t.co/PA8M0I7rge https://t.co/0nQiI5vEPy

Changing with the times.  A peek into the future of the IMF’s work and the changes on the horizon.  #CSR
 https://t.co/rteq32nANa https://t.co/K4QKa59KDA

To help our policy advice keep up with the times, we took a sneak peek into what the future could look like with 3 scenarios about the increasing reach of corporations, protecting the planet, and the boons and banes of big data.  #CSR

Find out more: https://t.co/IFTR64QHO8 https://t.co/heKsn8p5ip

🔴 STARTING NOW: @KGeorgieva and @Lagarde on "Gender, Money and Finance" at @oenb's 1st Vienna Economic Dialogue, in cooperation with @suerf_org & @jvi_vienna. #WomenInEconomics

Watch LIVE here: https://t.co/732VhL7Zu0 https://t.co/oaILqqbPFz

Deputy Managing Director Antoinette M. Sayeh: Big, consequential issues such as fighting a pandemic, climate change, reducing inequality—they all transcend national borders. We must work together to tackle them. #ChamberGlobalForum @USChamber

Watch here: https://t.co/9Vgq4CUrKe https://t.co/A7YL0PeKA1
🔴 STARTING NOW: Deputy Managing Director Antoinette M. Sayeh joins the #ChamberGlobalForum session on Multilateral Solutions to Global Challenges. Watch LIVE here: https://t.co/NV3o7EGTxd

Sub-Saharan Africa has huge development needs. Mobilizing more financing for private sector projects in social and physical infrastructure can help address the gap. More in our latest departmental paper: https://t.co/gdSVwKddP8 #IMFAfrica https://t.co/MibWip3Bw0

COMING SOON: The Comprehensive Surveillance Review

The pandemic has shown how events in one country can have a global impact.  The IMF is strengthening its work to assess the economic health of countries and the global economy.

https://t.co/5fZ1gZIzLp https://t.co/yORO5u7R6J

Deputy Managing Director Antoinette M. Sayeh joins the first #ChamberGlobalForum, where she will share perspectives on the multilateral approaches needed to solve global challenges. 

Watch LIVE May 19 @ 9:00AM ET https://t.co/dvwP58VyvE https://t.co/41CiD02yrF

Our new estimate is that Africa needs additional financing of around $285 billion for COVID response through 2025. @KGeorgieva outlined the need for urgent actions to help Africa get back on track at today's Africa Finance Summit hosted by @EmmanuelMacron. https://t.co/1A7g2aNpfw https://t.co/5Dll9AFaD7

Statement by @KGeorgieva ahead of the Summit on the financing of African economies: “We have to boost growth, public and private investment in Africa by mobilizing financing from international organizations, from bilateral donors, and of course, from the countries themselves." https://t.co/mPCQgzFu7Z

Private finance could bring at least 3% of GDP of financing to private or semi-private development projects annually in sub-Saharan Africa by the end of the decade. More in our latest departmental paper: https://t.co/gdSVwKddP8 #IMFAfrica https://t.co/td6wo77BzU

Managing Director @KGeorgieva will join President @EmmanuelMacron of France and @Presidence_RDC Tshisekedi at the concluding press conference of the Summit on the Financing of African Economies today, at 12:00 PM ET. Watch LIVE here: https://t.co/BlATQwRaBR

IMF Managing Director @KGeorgieva's opening remarks at the Sudan conference's plenary session on "Delivering on Economic Promises and Moving Towards Sudanese Debt Forgiveness."
https://t.co/o6CxSAomoa https://t.co/lcEBbxVzKC

IMF’s Abe Selassie: What SDRs do really (well) is leverage the balance sheet of the entire membership. So you’re pulling everybody's resources to facilitate & create liquidity for the benefit of the global economy. 

Watch the replay here: https://t.co/hbPN8m8g6T #ParisPeaceForum https://t.co/Ia4bdzSXz0

At the @ParisPeaceForum Spring Meeting, @KGeorgieva and Abe Selassie discussed Africa’s road to recovery, how the IMF supported the region throughout the crisis, and how SDRs can help boost investment in infrastructure, education, and health. 

REPLAY ⬇️ 
https://t.co/nsjKnRl7cu https://t.co/b1TdUOENCb

What are the goals of Kenya’s economic program, supported by the IMF? 
1️⃣ Support pandemic response 
2️⃣ Help reduce debt vulnerabilities 
3️⃣ Address weakness in state-owned enterprises 
4️⃣ Support anti-corruption framework 

Learn more: https://t.co/c0F4BLmSQx #IMFAfrica https://t.co/ChquKqsIj9
Do you have questions about #Kenya's program with the IMF? Check out our FAQs page. https://t.co/cXCus75lu0 #IMFAfrica https://t.co/HvPMFg9mSH

IMF staff have concluded the first review of #Kenya's economic program. The government reiterated its determination to press ahead on transparency and fighting corruption and will soon publish an audit of all COVID-related expenditures for FY 2019/2020. https://t.co/YA3RmbbrbQ

IMF surveillance assesses the economic health of countries and the global economy and helps detect risks, so governments can take action.

.@KGeorgieva had productive meetings with 🇨🇮  @AOuattara_PRCI, 🇹🇬 @FEGnassingbe, and 🇷🇼 @PaulKagame to discuss Africa's digital & green transformational opportunities ahead of the International Conference on Sudan and the Summit on Financing African Economies in Paris this week. https://t.co/f41ti6yTUA

Sub-Saharan Africa will be the world's slowest-growing region in 2021, with economic activity growing by 3.4% in 2021. Here is our latest analysis for the region: https://t.co/cm2FeSbmym #IMFAfrica https://t.co/v9CKuzTuY5

Digitalization can transform economies and lives. But it needs to be inclusive with a focus on regulation, investment in digital skills and infrastructure. Our latest issue of F&D explores the digital future. https://t.co/mZENc2yjHL #IMFBlog https://t.co/ITOk8zyS6l

Rising interest rates in advanced economies have consequences for financial conditions in emerging markets. The April 2021 World Economic Outlook finds that the reason for the rise matters. https://t.co/2mJRBNv2JH #IMFBlog #WEO
Stock markets in countries with more open and democratic institutions weather social unrest better. Read our #IMFBlog: https://t.co/gAexSuy054 https://t.co/1ZdoC3q1jB
Africa’s policymakers face the unenviable task of trying to boost their economies while, at the same time, dealing with repeated COVID-19 outbreaks. https://t.co/XDGHB17L68 #IMFBlog #IMFAfrica

Low rates have helped with the early recovery in the commercial real estate sector. But easy financial conditions could encourage too much risk-taking and policymakers may need to turn to other policy tools. Read the latest #IMFBlog: https://t.co/POQuvOvOwp #GFSR https://t.co/jmJe2t3ZKN

The pandemic could increase the share of insolvent small and medium-sized businesses by as much as the global financial crisis did but over a much shorter period. Read more on #IMFBlog. https://t.co/ryATLihLj9
What is social spending and why is it so important for the future of our economies? https://t.co/sWTapw1A45 https://t.co/oZ4nv6owlp

Whenever digital cash emerges, will it replace private sector services or complement them? On #IMFBlog, Tobias Adrian and Tommaso Mancini-Griffoli argue that stability and innovation complement each other and can coexist in digital form. https://t.co/CWontAefwP #CBDCs #fintech

We project economic activity in sub-Saharan Africa to grow by 3.4% in 2021, after a decline of -1.9% in 2020, the slowest on record. 

Watch IMF's Abebe Aemro Selassie's overview and what can help improve the outlook. https://t.co/Ncxawl5Gnj #IMFAfrica https://t.co/L3IqoSNyy5

#China’s rapid economic development and unprecedented growth have been accompanied by a widening earnings gaps between men and women. Our latest research offers some policy solutions: https://t.co/JJdVtvKFHO https://t.co/YjAKHdZHTw

Women suffered large job losses during the pandemic and are coming back to work at a much slower pace than any other group. @cafreeland and @KGeorgieva on what to do about it... in this @imf_podcast. https://t.co/KwFbQ9hUQW https://t.co/QjJ45N0Bj6

When is a sovereign #debt restructuring needed? And why can sovereign debt restructurings be difficult to achieve? Learn more about the main challenges and how the IMF can facilitate a solution. https://t.co/HBjdqsuV4K https://t.co/XGjd4zqc4F

The gap between women’s & men’s participation in the work force nearly doubled in #China, rising from 9 percentage points in the 1990s to almost 15 percentage points in 2020. What can China do to combat rising #genderinequality? Read our latest research: https://t.co/JJdVtvKFHO https://t.co/TZOg3BLgeF

1. To meet increased spending needs 
2. To contain a pronounced increase in public debt
3. To mobilize more tax revenue
